results.title: Sunday's dog
results.creator_credit: Fionnuala Keith, Maddie Jamieson Goddard and Pepper Horman
results.brief_description:
When Sunday went to live with her grandmother she didn’t have any friends to play with. One day a stray dog walked down the lane behind her house. It was missing a tail and an ear. Nobody wanted it. Sunday made friends with the dog but it was taken away to the pound. Weeks passed. Dogs were adopted and other dogs were led away to a big blue door. Finally, Sunday found the dog at the pound and adopted him. When they got home, Sunday made him a special hat with two ears and a tail for him to wag. Creators: Pepper Horman, Maddie Jamieson Goddard, Fionnuala Keith, Jennifer Petroploulos, Lucy Hanna, Declan Warren, Piper McLeod, Amy Phillips, Elan Cotter, Georgia Dickie, Isabella Godfrey, Lucinda McSherry, Millie Barnes, Nick Warren, Ella O’Donoghue, Isobel Hyett, Michael Guzzardi, Lucy Phillips, Clare Olding and Jagger Skilbeck.

Under the category ‘Primary Animation’, Years 5 and 6, Yarraville West Primary School, Victoria, were the Screen It 2012 winners.

results.title: Proud 2 Be Me!
results.creator_credit: Isabelle Tonna, Amy Rowe, Jessica Smith, Charlotte Kinsella, Chloe McKenna, Leah Felsbourg and Hannah Petrowski
results.brief_description:
A story of a little, white monster who feels like he doesn’t belong. He tries to make himself fit in, which doesn’t quite work out. The other little monsters finally decide that they like the little white monster just the way he is.

Under the category ‘Bullying. No Way! - Primary’, Years 5 and 6, St Luke’s Primary School, Victoria, were the Screen It 2012 winners.

results.title: Omni
results.brief_description:
Finbar is a young man who is obsessed with pi. His fragile existence is thrown into tumult when he discovers a mysterious note in his locker…

Under the category ‘Secondary Live Action’, Blake Whelan, ACT, was the Screen It 2012 winner.

results.title: The Game
results.creator_credit: Laurence Gunther, Aden Porter, Joshua Ash-Miller and Schonn-Pierre Hirst
results.brief_description:
The theme of belonging is explored by looking at rejection based on stereotypes in the schoolyard, and the effect that had on the victim. Also shown in this animated short is the impact an accepting group has on that person.

Under the category ‘Bullying. No Way! - Secondary”, Year 10, St John’s Grammar School, South Australia, were the Screen It 2012 winners.

results.title: Cubbies
results.creator_credit: Max Duke, Darcy Drake, Kane Jutson and Ryan Dunt
results.brief_description:
Trust, creativity, friendship and belonging are the focus of the ‘Cubbies’ story. A group of friends use cooperation, creativity and sheer ingenuity to build 29 different ‘cubbies’. The trust given by the staff and wider school community is central.

Under the categories ‘Primary Live Action’ and ‘Best Overall Primary’, Years 5 and 6 from Doreen Primary School, Victoria, were the Screen It 2012 winners.

results.title: Game Masters: an evening with Tetsuya Mizuguchi
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Jim Arneman, ACMI Screen Events and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Join music gaming legend, artist and auteur, Tetsuya Mizuguchi, as he plays some of his seminal games and speaks about his signatory sound and visual fusion.

Famed for his pioneering application of music and visuals, Mizuguchi uses music not just as an accompaniment to a game, but as an integral part of its gameplay. Including traditional videogames, such as the hugely successful ‘Sega Rally Championship’, Mizuguchi has worked on some of the most original and unconventional music-fusion titles, including ‘Space Channel 5’, ‘Lumines’, ‘Rez’ and his latest opus, ‘Child of Eden’.

During this hosted conversation Mizuguchi explores how his vision has evolved over his career and demonstrates his pioneering application of music and visuals through live gameplay.

results.title: Game Masters: Rob Murray interview
results.brief_description:
In this interview, featured as part of the ‘Game Masters’ exhibition, Rob Murray speaks about his career as a game designer. Starting out as a solo developer for hire to becoming CEO of Firemint, Murray is one of the most successful indie game developers in existence.

Firemint’s success is due to Murray’s vision to create games such as ‘Flight Control’(2009) and’ Real Racing’ (2009), which are both easy to play and elegant and addictive in equal measure. In addition, his prescient reading of the drive towards personalised gaming, led by the ubiquity of social networking on mobile platforms, has kept his games on trend – ‘Flight Control’, for example, allows players to choose music from their personal libraries to accompany the game.

Rob talks about the rise of mobile based gaming and the development of ‘Flight Control’ and ‘Real Racing’ .

results.title: Celebrations
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: A documentary film presenting six different and authentic celebrations involving people in the multicultural community of Melbourne. Depicts an Aboriginal dance showing body decoration preparation, an Indonesian Muslim wedding celebration, an Australian child’s birthday party, a Greek nameday party, Christmas festivities and a Northern Italian Christmas celebration. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Jubilee and beyond
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal, Ross Campbell and Victoria. Audio-Visual Education Centre
results.brief_description: A non-narrated impression of the Royal visit to Melbourne, in the Queen’s Jubilee year, in 1977. Showing behind the scene preparations by the Army and Navy personnel, news crews, teachers and school children. The actual event is intercut with students from McRobertson Girls High School and Melbourne High School conducting a debate about the role of the Monarchy in Australia, touching on the issue of republic as an alternative. A good discussion starter on a ‘hot’ issue. (Includes shot of the half-built Westgate Bridge and Melbourne city skyline).
